title: In Search Of: Flourishes
content:
One of my students is looking for “fonts that have the same  
flourishes that Hoefler Italic and Caslon Italic have”. Since  
I know there’s a small horde of flourish junkies on Typophile,  
I figured to just ask on her behalf.

hhp

 [‹ Does anyone have access to a Linotype machine?](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201164928/http:/typophile.com/node/17440 "Go to previous forum topic") [Clients Who Make Me Sweat ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201164928/http:/typophile.com/node/18465 "Go to next forum topic")
author: hrant

comments.content:
[Farnham](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201164928/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Farnham)?

Btw, congrats on Patria and Nour, I just got my copy of Creative Review!

_MMmmmmm... Swashes!_  
 — Homer Simpson

[The Lanston Type](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201164928/http:/www.p22.com/lanston/products/kennerley.html) section of P22 has quite a few well and lesser known historic types with swash, alternates and fleurons.

The ’bakermat’ (dutch for ’cradle’ or ’birth-place’) of such swashes is the mannerist cancellerescian majuscule. The reference majuscules throughout page 63-69 of my [Raffia Intials presentation](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201164928/http:/www.enneson.com/public_downloads/pe/HKs_RIs.pdf) are drawn from a book whose title and author escapes me at the moment, but the book shows as many variations for each letter of the alphabet. I might be able to dig out bibliographic particulars on the source on the weekend if it would be of use.

But do you really want to send your student down a chirographic detour?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201164928im_/http:/typophile.com/files/%5D%5Bimg:)
Poetica is has a festival of swash characters. Many of Slimbach’s faces have them, as he is very good at them.
Don’t forget Auto and Sauna from Underware!
or Typofonderie’s Le Monde or ITC Bodoni Seventy-two or Palatino

[I ran a search for “Swash” over at Veer, and this is what I came up with.](http://web.archive.org/)

I think the two latest additions are the new [Bookman Complete](http://web.archive.org/) and [Whomp](http://web.archive.org/).

Typically great help guys.

\> But do you really want to send your student down a chirographic detour?

:-\>  
I would like my students to walk the world, critically, taking  
[provisional] decisions that will make them happier than not.

This particular student for example is considering attending this:  
 [http://www.viavide.com/summerexperiences/type\_design\_d\_roos.xml](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201164928/http:/www.viavide.com/summerexperiences/type_design_d_roos.xml "http://www.viavide.com/summerexperiences/type\_design\_d\_roos.xml") \_  
And I’m encouraging her (even though she could buy a lot of great type  
books with all that money :-)... but not least because she’s already armed  
with my chirographic caveats! :-\> Anyway - as you were.

hhp

Here is the promised reference:

Kathryn A. Atkins,  
Masters of the Italic Letter: Twenty-two Exemplars from the Sixteenth Century  
David R. Godine, Publisher, Inc., Boston, Massachusetts  
(I don’t have the publication date)

Additional Fonts with swash caps:  
Baskerville, Cooper Black Italic, Deepdene Italic, Garamond Italic, Kennerly Italic, but you might need to go into the metal books to see them (I’m not sure to what extent swash cap components of common pre-digital faces were routinely digitized).

You’ve reminded me of the particular “swash factor” in Baskerville.  
Because the original italic caps had a strange “swash distribution”,  
in that some glyphs were very “straight” while others were overly  
swashy, revivers of Baskerville have elected to either preserve the  
original scheme or do away with the swashes entirely. One elegant  
solution can be found in ATF’s metal Baskerville: non-swashy main  
sorts, but swashy, in fact extra-swashy, alternates. Here’s a scan  
from a print I did at Archetype last year:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071201164928im_/http:/typophile.com/files/BvilleATF_SwashCaps.gif)
